title-group.article-title: High Speed Drilling of Al-2024-T3 Alloy

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2003 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: The competitive market has forced the industry to develop methodologies to reduce lead-time of the products without sacrificing quality. One of the major metal removal operations in the aerospace industries is drilling. Over 100,000 holes are made for a small single engine aircraft. Naturally, demand for faster production rate results in the demand for high-speed drilling. But the cost of holemaking operations becomes a significant portion of the total manufacturing cost. This paper discusses the high speed drilling of Al-2024-T3 alloy, the effect of feed and speed on hole quality features like oversize, roundness error, burr height and surface roughness.

ref.mixed-citation: B. Bahr and T. Mankand, "Study of Drill Tool Geometry in High-Speed Drilling of Aluminum Sheet Metal", SAE Transactions, 108, part 5 pp 1040- 1044.1999.
Peter Zelinski, "The Fast Track to High Speed Drilling", Modern Machine Shop, vol71 n1 pp 62 (10), 1998.
D.F. Galloway, "Some Experiments on the Influence of Various Factors on Drill Performance", Transactions of the ASME, pp191-231, 1995.
S. Elma, H.Fujii and E. Marui, "Chatter Vibration in Drilling", Journal of Engineering for Industry vol 110 pp 309-321, 1998.

A. Thangaraj and M. Langenstein. "Investigation into the Relationships between Hole Quality and Drilling Forces. Proceedings of Manufacturing International '90. Part 4: Advances in Materials and Automation, pp 149-157, 1990.
L. Ken Lauderbaugh Saunders and Craig A. Mauch, "An Exit Burr Model for Drilling of Metals", Proceedings of the ASME, pp 187-192, 1998.
S.S Pande and H.P. Relekar, "Investigations on Reducing Burr Formation in Drilling", International Journal of Machine Tool design and Research, vol 26, 3, pp 339-348, 1986.
Basile A. Stephen, " Modeling Transverse Motions of a Drill Bit for Process Understanding", Precision Engineering, vol 15, 4, pp 258-264, 1993.
